Your point about the less populated states having more power, through the US Senate, is well taken. Additionally, the Republicans have a lock on a number of lower population states and they want to keep it. Yet, aside from farm subsidies, I have never seen a careful analysis of the effect of the deliberately undemocratic US Senate on giving out federal funds. It is generally true, however, that the heavily populated states, which tend toward the Democrats, send out more of their tax dollars to the smaller states than they get back, while, in turn, those states favor Republicans.

This whole thing resembles a secret deal whereby peace, but not justice or fairness, is kept within the lower 48 states. Competing interests are melded into one, somewhat happy exchange. Yet, with the Republicans on the warpath, threatening to destroy America's "full faith and credit" for debt obligations, maybe it is time to re-examine this huge trade off of conflicting interests. It has allowed those who oppose everything the populous states need to get more in federal programs than their paid taxes. Perhaps it is time for change.

If gobal climate change brings about truly dramatic challenges to how we must live our lives, then democracy, the most legitimate but the least efficient form of government, may have had its day. We made need a dictator to define who wins and who loses; and to make it stick.

Climate change is real. Growing regions are changing.

But the growing regions are not disappearing, they are moving. In Europe, grapes no longer grow where they once grew, but they do grow on other hillsides where before they would not grow.

The questions are two: 1) How much will the present growing regions be able to grow after these changes, and of what; and 2) what new regions will open up to replace them.

Yes we will lose something. We will not lose it all. We will also gain something.

The real issue is the net, the net effect. Will we lose more, or gain more, and where?

Some countries are likely to be hurt badly. Some others will have far better growing conditions. How will it net out? How will the change be managed?

I fear the answers are that the net will be ignored and the change will be handled badly.

We ought not to have gotten ourselves into this mess. We did. We don't seem to be changing very much about that.

Still, realism about where to go from here is called for, not panic, not doomsaying.

This is a classic crisis of belief when one faces evidence-based reality. All religions are the products of mankind's creativity--the result of a struggle to formulate a narrative that explains the cosmic, awesome reality we find ourselves living in. There are multiple types of truth including factual truth, emotional (--based) truth, and what I choose to call, meta-truth. The latter is that which is formed by a critical mass of people who choose to believe and support a communal narrative.

All of us are born with "an imperative to create a narrative;" it's wired into the genome. It began with primitive humans who needed it badly to find safety in a dangerous, predatory world. These narratives spread out to incorporate all forms and categories we experience, the physical, social, spiritual, religious, psychological, relationships, etc. Once they are formed, especially religious, social and political ones, co-believers are driven by the the need to be exclusively correct--to claim, "We have the only true belief."

When dispassionate, unfettered research demonstrates a genuine realities that are a contradiction to them, some of us can't handle the disparity. Cognitive dissonance sets in. The threat is too much for the psyche and the ego--the security we seek.

Overall, it's an incredible scene. The Singularity expressing itself in unending multiplicity. How do any of us have the gall to conclude that, "ours is THE only way."

And notice that Elder Jensen was quickly marginalized (made "emeritus") soon after his candid statements about the exodus from the Mormon Church.

That is how the Mormon cult works: anyone who does not "build the kingdom" at any and all costs (even at the expense of truth itself), must be run over, moved aside, or destroyed.

This is a dangerous cult.

Southern Ontario, as part of Ontario has made real efforts to deal with racism. There are, for the most part, reasonably effective ways for people of differing ethnic minority backgrounds to move up the economic ladder.

That's not to say that Canada hasn't had issues with racial discrimination (it has) and that we can't do a better job in some quarters (we can). But that history hasn't played out in the shape (and condition) of our cities because we have different divisions of powers between the provincial and municipal levels of government, and have also chosen to pursue fairly cohesive and targeted industrial development policies to get shuttered industrial lands repurposed and back into use as new facilities. We have, as a general rule, less fighting between the provincial and municipal levels of government, and compared to the U.S., a significantly less complicated regulatory environment. It's a smaller population. It's cold in the winter. We have to work together.

Detroit's problems are similar to Birmingham, AL's, and I'd say structurally linked, in that both cities were dominated by one major industry in the early twentieth century, (cars in Detroit, iron and steel in Birmingham) with strong interests in remaining the dominant employer within region. Racism is a handy tool for dividing the working masses. As a Canadian, I understood this intellectually, but didn't _really_ get it until I moved south and started repeatedly bumping into all the unspoken assumptions.

As a recent visitor to Detroit, I'm saddened but not surprised by the bankruptcy. Detroit's CBD is shrunken and its streets and highways are ominously quiet during rush hours. The city has been forced to maintain municipal infrastructure that is not supported by the economic base.

To blame Detroit's collapse on its municipal unions is gross over-simplification. The need now is to find a way forward. Yes, municipal unions will no doubt need to cut benefits. But political will and creative solutions, including federal support, will likely need to be part of a long-term fix.

The U.S. bailed out Wall Street five years ago, and provided much-needed financial support to the auto industry. Can we muster the political will to assist a major American city in its hour of need? The question is political as much as it is financial.
